item.title: Voting for lizards
item.description:
Douglas Adams, “So long, and thanks for all the fish”

"It comes from a very ancient democracy, you see..." <br />
"You mean, it comes from a world of lizards?" <br />
"No," said Ford, who by this time was a little more rational and coherent than he had been, having finally had the coffee forced down him, "nothing so simple. Nothing anything like so straightforward. On its world, the people are people. The leaders are lizards. The people hate the lizards and the lizards rule the people." <br />
"Odd," said Arthur, "I thought you said it was a democracy." <br />
"I did," said Ford. "It is." <br />
"So," said Arthur, hoping he wasn't sounding ridiculously obtuse, "why don't people get rid of the lizards?" <br />
"It honestly doesn't occur to them," said Ford. "They've all got the vote, so they all pretty much assume that the government they've voted in more or less approximates to the government they want."
"You mean they actually vote for the lizards?"
"Oh yes," said Ford with a shrug, "of course."
"But," said Arthur, going for the big one again, "why?"
"Because if they didn't vote for a lizard," said Ford, "the wrong lizard might get in."

item.title: Introductions
item.description:
I like sharing and learning, especially to and from passionate people.

I like meeting new people but wondered about what to say first. At meetups and conferences, friends of friends, there’s a lot you don’t know.

“What do you do for a living?” is obvious and popular. It’s a bit sad to be defined by your job: some hate it, some have none. Some love their job but it’s a bit sad to have it be your whole personality.

“What’s new? What interesting things are you doing?” First, it can be alienating for people standing out in a crowd. Think significant others at a conference, or with university friends.

I tried going with “what do you do or love, except your job?” It’s pretty nice and is a great conversation opener because it’s uncommon.

It can set people off balance: if they are shy or introverts, they often have a premade speech that’s proven, works good, or keeps them in control.

Whenever I felt some awkwardness, I quickly add “well, it’s fine talking about your job, especially if you love it”. But don’t worry, they’ll tell you.

If they have a startup, it’s probably harder to make them shut up about it anyway ;) (full disclosure: I was and still can be like that – sorry)

So I’ve settled for a weird mix I try to formulate on the spot. The idea is “what are you currently finding interesting, what last startled you, what uncommon thing do you love”.

item.title: Smalltalk
item.description:
As a kid I hated chit-chat. > Why saying useless things? Do you feel lonely? > I don’t, leave me alone. > I’m not interested in discussing the weather!

Trying to engage in smalltalk is acknowledging the recipiten as a fellow human. It’s saying > hello, I saw you and want you to know you’re not a nobody to me > but deserve some of my time.

I still don’t see much point in discussing the weather, but I’m glad you came to me. I hope we’ll soon find an opening to anything that’s interesting to you, me, or both!

item.title: HADOPI
item.description:
Je n’ai pas compris le manque d’outrage contre HADOPI. La loi est compliquée, Internet est compliqué. Laissez-moi faire une analogie pour comprendre le souci.

Il me semble que l’électeur français aime sa voiture. Il me semble que les radars partout ont énervé les français.

HADOPI n’est pas un radar de plus. L’idée était un “mouchard de l’État” dans votre ordinateur.

C’est à dire : une boîte noire dans votre voiture qui, dès que vous dépassez la limite de vitesse ou grillez un feu rouge, même sans policier alentour, vous êtes pris et payez une amende.

Ça fait peur ? Probablement pas, parce que c’est passé. Et qu’on se prépare à faire mieux.

item.title: The Customers startup
item.description:
The Funds startup grows with someone else’s money. That’s a dangerous game.
The Grants startup eats up the taxpayers’ money. That’s a hurtful game.

The Customers startup kind focuses on solving problems in a way people are willing to pay for.

It’s long, it’s hard, it needs you to rework many assumptions, and it often doesn’t grow as fast, nor look as sexy.

But it’s the only kind of startup I respect.

You can be solving problems people could pay for, but not in the way you put forward. Change, or die. But you do have my sympathy.

Or perhaps you found a way to extract money from people while not really solving problems. I don’t particularly like you but you’re playing a wrong game right, so, well, why not?

item.title: The Grants startup
item.description:
The Funds startup grows with someone else’s money. It’s a system that makes money out of young, hard-working, gullible cogs. And it has money to publicize and romanticize themselves for the next generation of cogs.

The Grants startup kind is similar to the Funds startup, only with grants.

In the end, the people you’re scamming or hurting are the taxpayers. Which is, everyone.

The people you’re courting are the governments, which are often clueless: - if you’re doing a great thing, they probably don’t have a structure that allows them to recognize that - if you’re doing a new thing, they probably are too scared or not ready for that - if you’re just looking for easy cash from a crazy system, you’re a parasite

Like Funds startups, this kind need to look sexy: for the next round, for the next laborers, or for the public. You need to show encouragement or any form of ROI, so the money gone will not look like a total loss.

Accepting the government’s money comes with the responsibility to do something useful and in line with the powers in place. So you will only be hindered in your creativity and experiments.

item.title: The Funds startup
item.description:
The Funds startup kind wants to raise funds, and to have a nice exit.

What’s the matter about an Exit? You’re not building for the long term. If you want funds but no nice exit, you will give up control to people who will.

What’s the matter about raising funds? First, you’re losing time from your product. Then, you are borrowing money, so you will have to pay it back. For real, or in a scammy plot. Last big buyers lose, and will take it out on customers.

It’s not sexy to toil in those meatshops. You’re just a cog. But that system makes money, and needs more cogs. And it has money to publicize and romanticize themselves for the next generation of cogs.

item.title: Three kinds of startups
item.description:
A startup is a company. It’s not a charity. It wants to make money. In my mind, there are three kinds of startups, related to how they make money:

  • the Funds startup
  • the Grants startup
  • the Customers startup

The Funds startup grows with someone else’s money. It’s a system that makes money out of young, hard-working, gullible cogs. And it has money to publicize and romanticize themselves for the next generation of cogs.

— — —

The Grants startup is quite the same as above, only with grants.

The people you’re courting are the governments, which are often clueless.

In the end, the people you’re scamming or hurting are the taxpayers. Everyone.

Both these kinds need to look sexy: for the next round, for the next laborers, or for the public. You need to show encouragement or any form of ROI, so the money gone will not look like a total loss.

— — —

The Customers startup is focusing on solving problems in a way people are willing to pay for.

It’s long, it’s hard, it needs you to rework many assumptions, and it often doesn’t grow as fast, nor look as sexy.

But it’s the only kind of startup I respect.

You can be solving problems people could pay for, but not in the way you put forward. Change, or die. But you do have my sympathy.

Or perhaps you found a way to extract money from people while not really solving problems. I don’t particularly like you but you’re playing a wrong game right, so, well, why not?

item.title: I love/hate startups
item.description:
I love the idea of startups:

  • most of the philosophy: move fast, fail fast, learn fast.
  • the people who want to change the world, or change the status quo.
  • and I love the underdogs, perhaps that’s a french thing.

I hate the implementation of startups:

  • the arrogance, monoculture and exclusion
  • the young people toiling and hurting their health, life and loved ones
  • the belief that everything has to raise funds

I know the arrogance is somehow necessary: if you don’t believe hard, you wouldn’t try. Luckily the market cures that for you: people either become more humble, or bitter. And rarely the arrogant kind who had luck in the first place and thinks it’s his talent.

item.title: On Structured Content
item.description:
I’m forcing myself to small-sized chunks of content.

There’s also two experiments I’d like to make, linking bits of my opinions to the others:

  1. make their relationships obvious
  2. not mixing ideas and having them as atomic as possible
  3. finding myself which bits of my philosophy most shape my ideas
  4. finding which bits of my philosophy are most useful / explain most things
  5. running a PageRank or reverse-PageRank algo on it to find the “roots” of it

I suppose this requires a discipline and a lot of rework I probably won’t be able / courageous enough to make. But it’d be nice to try, and if someone else does it I’d find it interesting and motivating :)

Cheers,
